newsitem.title: SAUDI ARABIA: Small European firms seek deals in Gulf markets.
newsitem.headline: Small European firms seek deals in Gulf markets.

text.p: Small and mid-sized European firms are eager to cash in on lucrative Gulf consumer markets and invest in a region which is still uncharted territory for many, delegates at a Gulf-EU business conference said on Wednesday.

Many of the 120 European firms attending the three-day conference in Riyadh are looking to the oil-rich Gulf as an export market for their goods, such as food and beverages, chemical products and construction materials, they said.
Other firms are seeking to establish joint ventures in the region.

"The financial strength of the region is promising and clients are able to pay," said Thorsten Hildebrand, adviser at the chamber of commerce in Magdeburg, Germany, which brought 16 companies to the conference.
The German delegation of 27 companies is the largest at the meeting, followed by France with 25 firms and Italy with 15.

Several companies attending the European Union-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) forum said the region -- especially Saudi Arabia -- was a good export market because about half the population of around 25 million is under the age of 16.

In addition, per capita income in the GCC -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates -- is among the world's highest, ranging from about $7,000 a year in Saudi Arabia and Oman to $16,800 in Kuwait.
Miriam Teuwen, national counsellor of the German team, agreed the conference was helping firms break into the market.
"Yesterday one German company made contact with a Saudi firm. Today the German firm visited the Saudi one and made a sale of 10,000 marks ($5,900). He thinks it's just the beginning," she said.
Some European and Gulf companies reported the conference had paved the way for possible joint ventures.
"I have held talks with three or four potential joint venture companies," said a representative of a Saudi medical group.
Several European companies were also seriously considering joint venture deals, one EU representative said.
In the absence of the developed capital markets in the region, liquid Gulf firms are keen to couple their money with companies which already have established businesses and brands.

Hussein Mirghani, economic adviser at the Federation of GCC Chambers of Commerce, said while GCC investments in Europe amounted to about $150 billion to date, European investments in Gulf Arab states barely exceeded $2 billion.
